articles.headline: Countless Lost Limbs Alter Life in Haiti’s Ruins
articles.snippet: New amputees are facing life in a shattered country that has never been hospitable to the disabled.
articles.abstract: New amputees are facing life in a shattered country that has never been hospitable to the disabled.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  “Don’t cut off my leg!” Fabienne Jean screamed repeatedly as she was carried through the gates of the General Hospital here after the earthquake. “I’m a dancer. My leg is my livelihood. Please, don’t take my leg.”

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Adds Its Clout to Movie Streaming
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart’s purchase of the start-up Vudu represents a major move into selling movies over the Internet.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart’s purchase of the start-up Vudu represents a major move into selling movies over the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, you took the plunge and bought that expensive high-definition television. But does it connect to the Internet?

articles.headline: Lawmakers’ Ties to Toyota Questioned at Start of Inquiries
articles.snippet: Watchdog groups are questioning whether deep financial and personal connections between U.S. lawmakers and Toyota could taint inquiries.
articles.abstract: Watchdog groups are questioning whether deep financial and personal connections between U.S. lawmakers and Toyota could taint inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Congress prepares to open hearings on Tuesday into Toyota’s rash of safety problems, government watchdog groups are questioning whether the deep financial and personal connections between lawmakers and the carmaker could taint the inquiries.

articles.headline: Banks Apply Pressure to Keep Fees Rolling In
articles.snippet: As the government cracks down on overdraft fees, banks are mounting an aggressive campaign aimed at retaining billions of dollars in penalty income.
articles.abstract: As the government cracks down on overdraft fees, banks are mounting an aggressive campaign aimed at retaining billions of dollars in penalty income.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many households trying to improve their finances, tossing out pitches from the bank has become almost automatic. But in recent weeks, Chase has been fanning special letters out to consumers with an offer that it urges them not to refuse.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: In Passage of Jobs Measure, a Glimpse of Bipartisanship
articles.snippet: Five Republicans defected to support the measure’s advance after Senator Scott Brown expressed backing for the Democrats’ bill.
articles.abstract: Five Republicans defected to support the measure’s advance after Senator Scott Brown expressed backing for the Democrats’ bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five Republican senators broke ranks with their party on Monday to advance a $15 billion job-creation measure put forward by Democrats, a rare bipartisan breakthrough after months in which Republicans had held together to a remarkable degree in an effort to thwart President Obama’s agenda.

articles.headline: Apple Bans Some Apps for Sex-Tinged Content
articles.snippet: Hoping for a family-oriented future for its iPad, Apple is looking more closely at what is for sale in its App Store.
articles.abstract: Hoping for a family-oriented future for its iPad, Apple is looking more closely at what is for sale in its App Store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has started banning many applications for its iPhone that feature sexually suggestive material, including photos of women in bikinis and lingerie, a move that came as an abrupt surprise to developers who had been profiting from such programs.

articles.headline: Duane Reade and Its Road to Health
articles.snippet: Duane Reade is as much a story about selling milk and toothpaste at 2 a.m. as it is about Wall Street, financial engineering and shifts in the private equity industry.
articles.abstract: Duane Reade is as much a story about selling milk and toothpaste at 2 a.m. as it is about Wall Street, financial engineering and shifts in the private equity industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good thing Duane Reade is in the pharmacy business.

articles.headline: Toyota Official Says Recall May Not Fully Solve Safety Problem
articles.snippet: An executive told a House committee Toyota’s recall might “not totally” solve the problem of unintended acceleration in its vehicles.
articles.abstract: An executive told a House committee Toyota’s recall might “not totally” solve the problem of unintended acceleration in its vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the first of many Congressional hearings into Toyota’s extensive recalls, a senior company executive told the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Tuesday that the repairs prescribed by the company might “not totally” solve the problem of unintended sudden acceleration in its vehicles.

articles.headline: White House in New Push for Changes on Wall St.
articles.snippet: The Obama administration reiterated its desire for stricter trading rules and a consumer agency as it worked to refine regulations in the wake of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration reiterated its desire for stricter trading rules and a consumer agency as it worked to refine regulations in the wake of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration redoubled its efforts on Tuesday to overhaul the nation’s financial regulations, saying it would not back down from its efforts to restrict the trading activities of banks and to create a consumer agency to regulate financial products.

articles.headline: At F.D.I.C. , Bracing for a Wave of Failures
articles.snippet: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it had placed 702 lenders on its list of “problem” banks, the most since 1993.
articles.abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it had placed 702 lenders on its list of “problem” banks, the most since 1993.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is bracing for a new wave of bank failures that could cost the agency many billions of dollars and further strain its finances.
